TitleMain.Title: The state of the nation's health care : a report from American internists on opportunities to improve medical care through better coverage, less red tape, better use of health information technology, and improved access to primary care doctors.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Philadelphia : American College of Physicians, [2004]

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The American College of Physicians (ACP) is the nation's largest medical specialty society and second-largest physician organization in the United States, representing over 115,000 doctors of internal medicine and medical students. For the past three years, the College has released an analysis of the state of the nation's health care as a prelude to President Bush's State of the Union address to Congress. The College hopes to influence federal policymakers to address problems and opportunities for improvement in the nation's health care that reflect the perspectives of practicing internists in the front lines of medical care delivery.

TitleMain.OtherInformation: [electronic resource] / Department of Health and Human Services, U.S. Food and Drug Administration.

PublicationInfo.Publisher: U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services, U.S. Food and Drug Administration,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Congress addressed the importance of research related to rapid detection of adulterated food in the Bioterrorism Act with the inclusion of section 302(d). This section directs the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to provide for research on test methods and sampling methodologies designed to test food in order to rapidly detect the adulteration of the food. The greatest priority is to be given to the detection of the intentional adulteration of food and in the development of tests that are suitable for inspections of foods at ports of entry into the U.S. Research efforts are to be aimed at improving existing technology in terms of accuracy, timing and costs. Section 302 provides for the Secretary, as appropriate, to coordinate such research with certain other federal officials.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Title from title screen (viewed on Feb. 19, 2009).

TitleMain.Title: The Americans with Disabilities Act and community integration : an update on "fundamental alteration" litigation
TitleMain.OtherInformation: / by Sara Rosenbaum, Taylor Burke, and Joel Teitelbaum.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: Resource paper (Center for Health Care Strategies). 258
Resource paper (Center for Health Care Strategies).

Author.OtherInformation: The George Washington University Medical Center, School of Public Health and Health Services, Center for Health Services Research and Policy.

Author.CollectiveName: Center for Health Care Strategies, Inc.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Hamilton, N.J.] : Center for Health Care Strategies, Inc., [2003]
PublicationInfo.Publisher: Center for Health Care Strategies, Inc.,

Abstract.AbstractText: This Resource Paper, which updates an earlier paper prepared for CHCS, examines the continuing evolution of the "fundamental alteration/reasonable modification" issue that lies at the heart of the United States Supreme Court's 1999 decision in Olmstead v L.C. In Olmstead, which focused on the obligations of public programs to achieve "community integration" of qualified persons with disabilities under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Court set out a definitive but broad standard for measuring the adequacy of public program performance under the ADA. This standard continues to reverberate through the courts today; in particular, the test has been applied in a series of Medicaid cases of great importance to the issue of community integration. This Resource Paper begins with a brief recap of the basic community integration principles set forth in Olmstead and the reasonable modification/fundamental alteration dichotomy which the decision revealed. It then examines and classifies the types of community integration lawsuits that have emerged post-Olmstead. It concludes with a discussion of the implications of these cases for the development and progress of disability-related health policy.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: "Funded by the Center for Health Care Strategies, Inc. under The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation's Medicaid Managed Care Program."

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: "FRONTLINE examines the battle between major pharmaceutical companies and American consumers fed up with paying the highest drug prices in the world. TitleMain.Title: Alcohol marketing and advertising : a report to Congress.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Washington, D.C. : U.S. Federal Trade Commission, 2003]

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The Commission's investigation of flavored malt beverages (FMBs) indicates that adults appear to be the intended target of FMB marketing, and that the products have established a niche in the adult market. The investigation found no evidence of targeting underage consumers in the FMB market. FMB marketers placed advertisements in conformance with the industry standard that at least 50% of the advertisement's audience consists of adults age 21 and over. Nevertheless, the 50% placement standard in effect in 2001 and 2002 permitted the ads to reach a substantial youth audience. This is particularly significant where the products and some ad themes may be attractive to minors. Although it is probable that some teens drink FMBs, teen drinking continued to decline during the period when these beverages were being aggressively marketed.

TitleMain.Title: Is your emergency department prepared for a nuclear, biological, or chemical attack?

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Secaucus, N.J. : Network for Continuing Medical Education, c2003.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: September 11, 2001, marked a renewed effort to ensure that the nation's health care facilities and their staff were prepared to deal with a major disaster arising from the use of weapons of mass destruction (WMD). The newly created Department of Homeland Security, in collaboration with the Centers for Disease Control, Johns Hopkins Center for Civilian Biodefense Studies, and other nongovernmental organizations, have worked to establish guidelines and consensus statements to assist hospital and medical centers in developing and implementing emergency preparedness plans. Recent mock disaster drills around the country, ranging from "dirty bombs" to release and exposures to biochemical agents, have helped to identify areas of continued vulnerability and to focus on needed adaptations of existing plans. Dr. Jasper reviews the latest information on emergency preparedness and discusses the lessons learned from recent disaster-management exercises.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: ACCME-accredited sponsor: the Network for Continuing Medical Education ; approved for up to 2 credit hours in category 1 (PRA/AMA) ; for 1 prescribed hour (AAFP) ; AMA category 1 credit accepted (AAPA) ; and up to 2 credit hours in category 2A (AOA).

TitleMain.Title: Dirty bomb
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / produced by Kirk Wolfinger, Matthew Collins, Kim Shillinglaw ; a BBC/WGBH Boston co-production ; additional production for Nova by Lone Wolf Pictures.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Boston] : WGBH Boston Video, c2003.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: 1 videocassette (60 min.) : sd. col. with b&w sequences ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: In this important film, Nova goes beyond the alarming headlines to answer critical questions: How easy is it to make a dirty bomb, and how does it differ from a conventional nuclear bomb? What would happen if terrorists were to explode a dirty bomb in the middle of London or Washington, DC? How dangerous is the fallout from a dirty bomb? What are the long-term effects and how well do we really understand them? And how can lives be saved if one explodes?

This video is produced with the permission of the BBC.

TitleMain.Title: Protecting personal health information in research : understanding the HIPAA privacy rule.

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Dept. of Health and Human Services.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Washington, D.C.] : Dept. of Health and Human Services, [2003?]
PublicationInfo.Publisher: Dept. of Health and Human Services,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This booklet contains information about the "Privacy Rule," a Federal regulation under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) of 1996 that protects certain health information. The Privacy Rule was issued to protect the privacy of health information that identifies individuals who are living or deceased. The Rule balances an individual's interest in keeping his or her health information confidential with other social benefits, including health care research. This booklet provides researchers with a basic understanding of the Privacy Rule and how it may affect health research. It also addresses how researchers may be directly or indirectly affected by the Rule when their research requires the use of, or access to, an individual's identifiable health information.

TitleMain.Title: State-initiated nursing home nurse staff ratios : annotated review of the literature
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [electronic resource] / Kirsten Black, Barbara Ormond, Jane Tilly.

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Dept. of Health and Human Services. Office of Disability, Aging, and Long-Term Care Policy.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, DC : U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services, Asssistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, Office of Disability, Aging and Long-Term Care Policy, [2003]
PublicationInfo.Publisher: U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services, Asssistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, Office of Disability, Aging and Long-Term Care Policy,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The purpose of this project is to inform federal and state policymakers about what can be learned about the implementation and enforcement of state minimum nursing staff ratios for nursing homes, and related issues, such as labor shortages and resident casemix. The experiences of states that have already grappled with the complexities of setting, monitoring, and enforcing minimum staffing ratios could be instructive. The project will describe the states' minimum ratios and their goals, the issues states confront as they implement the ratios, and the perceived impacts of these ratios on the quality and cost of nursing home care.

TitleMain.Title: U.S. public policy and the biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life : some policy options.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: US public policy and the biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life
Staff working paper (President's Council on Bioethics (U.S.))

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Washington, D.C.] : President's Council on Bioethics, [2003]

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This paper aims to describe a range of general and specific public policy options in areas of biotechnology that touch on the beginnings of human life. In doing so, it builds directly on the diagnosis and findings of the Council's inquiry into these matters. It considers the different possibilities for institutional reform, examining the strengths and weaknesses of each major approach. Then, more specifically, it discusses several substantive areas of concern and the range of specific actions the country might take. It also discusses what specific actions or policies, if any, the Council might recommend in these areas. Using this document as a point of departure, the Coucil tries to discover any areas of common concern and agreement and whether there might be certain actions or policies that the Council might wish to recommend as interim steps, while continuing to seek a sound national policy in these areas of clinical practice and research that are at once novel and profound.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Title from title screen (viewed on June 24, 2004).
Mode of access: Internet from the PCB web site. Address as of 6/24/04: http://bioethics.gov/background/some%5Fpolicy%5Foptions.html; current access available via PURL.

TitleMain.Title: U.S. public policy and the biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life : findings.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: US public policy and the biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life
Staff working paper (President's Council on Bioethics (U.S.))

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Washington, D.C.] : President's Council on Bioethics, [2003]

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The fields of assisted reproduction, genetics, and human embryo research are increasingly converging. The fusion of genomic knowledge and assisted reproduction is no longer speculative. Techniques and practices, such as PGD, greatly enhance our control over human procreation and the character, fate, and future of our offspring. This document is an effort to enumerate the key findings growing out of the Council's survey and analysis of the current regulation of the biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Title from title screen (viewed on June 24, 2004).
Mode of access: Internet from the PCB web site. Address as of 6/24/04: http://bioethics.gov/background/human%5Flife%5Ffindings.html; current access available via PURL.

TitleMain.Title: U.S. public policy and the biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life : draft recommendations.

TitleOther.TitleAlternate: US public policy and the biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life
Staff working paper (President's Council on Bioethics (U.S.))

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Washington, D.C.] : President's Council on Bioethics, [2003]

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: After examining the current governance of the uses of biotechnologies that touch the beginnings of human life, practices arising at the intersection of assisted reproduction, genetic screening, and human embryo research, the Council has identified concerns that suggest the need for improved monitoring, oversight, and, perhaps, new forms of governmental regulation. The document notes that they are very far from being able to offer clear and well considered recommendations regarding major institutional reforms. Without the answers to many specific questions, it would be premature at best to recommend dramatic legal or institutional changes. They believe that further research and inquiry, and additional consultations with all the relevant actors, are clearly needed. These include a call for comprehensive information gathering, data collection, monitoring, and reporting of the uses and effects of these technologies. They also address the need for improving informed decision-making, consumer protection, and enforcement of existing guidelines for practitioners of assisted reproductive technologies (ART).

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Title from title screen (viewed on June 24, 2004).
Mode of access: Internet from the PCB web site. Address as of 6/24/04: http://bioethics.gov/background/bpprecommend.html; current access available via PURL.

TitleMain.Title: Enzyme-linked immunosorbant assays for identification of biological agents in sample unknowns : NATO SIBCA exercise IV
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [electronic resource] / H.G. Thompson and R.E. Fulton.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Ralston, Albta.] : Defence R&D Canada-Suffield, c2003.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: In Jan. 2002, SIBCA conducted the fourth international training exercise on identification of biological agents. The particiapting laboratory for Canada was Defence R&D Canada - Suffield. DRDC Suffield used a number of different technologies to screen the samples, one of which was the enzyme-linked immunosorbant assay (ELISA). This report describes the results obtained in screening the samples of 10 different biological agents by ELISA.
